The Student Council has proposed an astronomical budget.
The total expenses come to $5937,
representing an increase of approximately 1000 per cent.
The tremendous increase is
due to a major expansion of Student Council services. In a letter
sent to the administration, Bill
Reinsch, President of the Student Council, stated that "the
time has come for the Student
Council to fulfill the role of
leadership assigned to it on this
campus." In this atmosphere the
Student Council has budgeted
four new programs of major size
and expense.
The Discount Card System,
VISA—a network of local merchants providing discounts to
members, which has gone into
limited effect this spring, has
been allocated $500. This will
provide 500 cards at a cost to
the Student Council of one dollar
per card.

The Student Council has laid
the groundwork for a lecture series, consisting of 4 to 6 lectures.
An on the same topic, the series
will be an intensive examination
of a specific area of major interest to the Hopkins Community_
One proposal is for a three-day
symposium on Urban Affairs
with nationally known specialists. $2,000 has been requested
for this program.
The Council feels that the University must recognize the importance of the undergraduates
and meet their needs. It sees the
University moving toward this
outlook with the recent appointment of Robert Bilgrave to the
newly-created position of Director for Student Affairs. Mr. Bilgrave himself seems favorable to
this position. President Reinsch
noted that despite the tremendous, though justified increase,
the- budget is "primeval" in comparison with those of other universities.

We have seen the cat fall on four feet, rub its
muzzle on the window pane, and growl. The spring cat
is among us, and with him the growls of a winter of
discontent as well. Bananas, riots at Lauderdale, anti the

ones own sound—there are other growls that bear looking into.
The Board of Trustees at Columbia University voted
this past week to abolish an archaic remnant of graduate school requirements--class standing. In making the
decision, the trustees of that university cited the use of
class standings by draft boards, and the refusal of Columbia's administration to divulge class standing, as unauthorized trips into the political field. Political implications aside, this action of abolishing class standing has
greater ramifications in the academic world. Columbia
is the first major school in the country to make this step.
Haverford College previously voted to do away with
class ranking, and Bennington and Sarah Lawrence have
dropped grading systems as well as class standing. Princeton last year initiated a program of having one course
each term treated on the pass-fail scale. Goucher students also have this option.
It appears to 'us that in view of the recent activity
in reforming grading systems in higher education, there
should be serious thought given to changes in the current undergraduate ranking procedure at Hopkins. Entering into such a study would take one into the intricacies of the philosophy and psychology of grading in
the abstract, a discussion we will not enter into here.'
Suffice to say that consideration should he given to dropping class ranking as such and instituting, on a trial basis,
a pass-fail system. We hope both the academic circles
and the administration of Hopkins will not ignore their
tradition of innovation in considering any grade system
changes.
Several growls have been heard in the jungle of student affairs in the past few weeks that also require
comment.
The S.D.S. report on the University requirement of
freshmen living in dormitories has elicited little, if any,
reaction from the administration, at which it was aimed.
The report proposes a four point change in the current
administration policy that would lead to an abolishment
of the present rule. The University's policy, thrown out
on various disciplinary occasions, takes a view of the
Hopkins student as an adult, to be given all the privileges (apparently freedom) as well as the responsibilities
(apparently responsibility). If this philosophy is to be
applied consistently, it appears to us that the freshman
dormitory rule is contradictory. Does Hokins mold men
in the space of one year? We doubt it, and we also doubt
whether being forced to live in the dormitories- helps
matters.
The Student Council has submitted a budget that
exceeds that of previous years by a healthy sum in tight
fisted Hopkins' standards. The budget is merely a reflection of the Student Council's largely expanded services
this year. Included in the new budget would be allocations for the course guide, the discount card system,
and a lecture series. The only item that can be objected to is the proposed, and largely visionary, GoucherHopkins bus service. Improving the relation between the
sexes, or even between the two schools we do not view as
in the area of the Council's omnipotent authority, much
less concern. With the exception of this item we recommend that the budget be excepted.
A final growl comes from the direction of the
Homewood field. The growls are heard every Saturday,
and they are joyous sounds. We wish the lacrosse team
further growls as the season goes on.

Enough rhetoric is blown
around about this war to last at
least five more years of fighting
even if no one was to write another word. Student protest, as
is the case with just about all
other protest, contains as its
chief ingredient the same hot air,
the same tedious collections of
cliches and dragged out reasoning, the same over-involvement in
the sound of one's own words. If
one must protest I would suggest that burnt babies make a
more emphatic point. And the
point is not merely that burnt
children are useful items in a
propaganda campaign, but that
doing something about burnt children is somehow a less smug and
more humane approach to the entire Vietnamese misfortune than
simplistic ideologies—either for
the war or against it.
Politics Beside the Point
The political conflict is not up
for argument here. It would seem

that the care and treatment of
burnt children is something that
goes beyond one's convictions
about the relative merits of the
war. Discerning anyone's stake in
this war is difficult enough—certainly the Vietnamese themselves
are pretty much unaware of what
theirs is—ours is at best as unclear. But we are doing other
things in Vietnam than killing
Communists. And among the
things we are doing is causing
children to be burned quite
severely by the napalm bombs we
drop on these children's villages.
And if the civilians in the United
States cannot understand the political stakes being fought over,
it is shameful that there is not a
more widely held feeling of involvement with the present consequences of this war.
We hear a surfeit of talk about
protecting the future of freedom
in Vietnam. Yet it would seem
that the future of the Vietnamese
is in severe doubt no matter who
is triumphant in the military action. And even if we do find some
way to bring peace and freedom
to the people of Vietnam, what
good will it do them if their
country is populated chiefly by
cripples and burnt-out children?
Our stake in this unfortunate conflict at present can involve nothing more pressing than the most
effective rehabilitation of those
civilians whose lives have been
transformed by our peace-seeking
military operations. If our impressive
weaponry must be
turned upon the Vietnamese civilians as well as upon our armed
adversaries, then we ought at
least to have the simple grace
and decency to do more afterward than merely mop up the
blood.

The Board of Trustees at Columbia University voted
this past week to abolish an archaic remnant of graduate school requirements--class standing. In making the
decision, the trustees of that university cited the use of
class standings by draft boards, and the refusal of Columbia's administration to divulge class standing, as unauthorized trips into the political field. Political implications aside, this action of abolishing class standing has
greater ramifications in the academic world. Columbia
is the first major school in the country to make this step.
Haverford College previously voted to do away with
class ranking, and Bennington and Sarah Lawrence have
dropped grading systems as well as class standing. Princeton last year initiated a program of having one course
each term treated on the pass-fail scale. Goucher students also have this option.
It appears to 'us that in view of the recent activity
in reforming grading systems in higher education, there
should be serious thought given to changes in the current undergraduate ranking procedure at Hopkins. Entering into such a study would take one into the intricacies of the philosophy and psychology of grading in
the abstract, a discussion we will not enter into here.'

a pass-fail system. We hope both the academic circles
and the administration of Hopkins will not ignore their
tradition of innovation in considering any grade system
changes.

dormitory rule is contradictory. Does Hokins mold men

matters.
